articles.headline: These Boots Were Made for 22 M.P.H.
articles.snippet: The gas-powered shoe is a symbol of both Russia’s deep scientific traditions and the country’s inability to convert that talent into useful merchandise.
articles.abstract: The gas-powered shoe is a symbol of both Russia’s deep scientific traditions and the country’s inability to convert that talent into useful merchandise.
articles.lead_paragraph: UFA, Russia — Being a star engineering student at the top-notch science university here wasn’t enough to exempt Viktor K. Gordeyev from his physical education class.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Aim to Curb Loan Abuses
articles.snippet: Democrats fear that the rising number of homeowners who cannot repay their mortgages could cause broader economic problems.
articles.abstract: Democrats fear that the rising number of homeowners who cannot repay their mortgages could cause broader economic problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 16 — Senior Democrats in Congress, worried that the rising number of homeowners who cannot repay their mortgages could cause broader economic problems, have begun drafting legislation to curtail predatory lending practices.

articles.headline: Awaiting a Compromise on YouTube
articles.snippet: The problem for both Google and Viacom is that copyright law is filled with compromises and ambiguity.
articles.abstract: The problem for both Google and Viacom is that copyright law is filled with compromises and ambiguity.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Viacom is so ticked off at YouTube,” my son Nick informed me not long ago. “It’s just so obvious.”

articles.headline: Charisma and a Search for Self in Obama’s Hawaii Childhood
articles.snippet: The presidential candidate’s racial consciousness and political curiosity appear to have begun far from Illinois.
articles.abstract: The presidential candidate’s racial consciousness and political curiosity appear to have begun far from Illinois.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, March 12 — To his high school classmates, Barack Obama was a pleasant if undistinguished student, the guy who seemed happiest on the basketball court, the first to dive into the pumpkin carving at Halloween, the one whose oratorical prowess was largely limited to out-debating classmates over the relative qualities of point guards.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Abandons Bank Plans
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart abruptly withdrew its application to obtain a special banking charter after a firestorm of criticism.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart abruptly withdrew its application to obtain a special banking charter after a firestorm of criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few efforts illustrate the breadth of Wal-Mart’s ambitions  and the fears that they at times generate  as much as a nearly decade-long drive to establish its own bank.

articles.headline: Mortgage Trouble Clouds Homeownership Dream
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of families who bought houses in the last two years are being expelled into rental housing.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of families who bought houses in the last two years are being expelled into rental housing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the American dream of homeownership is not for everyone.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: A Titan of Private Equity May Go Public
articles.snippet: The Blackstone Group is preparing for an initial public offering that could value the firm at more than $30 billion.
articles.abstract: The Blackstone Group is preparing for an initial public offering that could value the firm at more than $30 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity may soon be going very public.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Edmonston

articles.headline: Iran Is Playing a Growing Role in Iraq Economy
articles.snippet: Iranian goods are flooding Iraqi markets and Iraqi cities are looking to Iran for basic services.
articles.abstract: Iranian goods are flooding Iraqi markets and Iraqi cities are looking to Iran for basic services.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAJAF, Iraq — While the Bush administration works to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, Iranian air-conditioners fill Iraqi appliance stores, Iranian tomatoes ripen on the windowsills of kitchens here and legions of white Iranian-made Peugeots sit in Iraqi driveways.

articles.headline: Airlines Learn to Fly on a Wing and an Apology
articles.snippet: Rather than rely entirely on weary front-line workers, many airlines are institutionalizing the apology.
articles.abstract: Rather than rely entirely on weary front-line workers, many airlines are institutionalizing the apology.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Airlines are getting serious about saying they’re sorry.

articles.headline: When Regulators Knock Twice
articles.snippet: Even dead cats bounce, as the idiom goes, and the stocks of subprime lenders did just that last week.
articles.abstract: Even dead cats bounce, as the idiom goes, and the stocks of subprime lenders did just that last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN dead cats bounce, as the idiom goes, and the stocks of subprime lenders did just that last week. Fremont General, a financial company with a big subprime unit that it is trying to sell, is up 51 percent since it disclosed that it had received a cease-and-desist order from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after the markets closed on March 2. The stock closed on Friday at $8.90.

articles.headline: The Barefoot Impresario
articles.snippet: Ina Garten has created a culinary empire that has been slow to spread roots but quick to grow in recent years.
articles.abstract: Ina Garten has created a culinary empire that has been slow to spread roots but quick to grow in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

articles.headline: Do You Know Where That Art Has Been?
articles.snippet: The new wariness of collectors to buy or exhibit works that do not have the most rigorously documented history jeopardizes the business of even the most established dealers.
articles.abstract: The new wariness of collectors to buy or exhibit works that do not have the most rigorously documented history jeopardizes the business of even the most established dealers.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE statue, Apollo the Lizard Slayer, was stunning. The five-foot-tall bronze, created by the Greek artist Praxiteles as many as 2,350 years ago, depicts the nude god poised to ambush a lizard.

articles.headline: Sunni Militants Disrupt Plan to Calm Baghdad
articles.snippet: Shiite militias had been seen as the main worry in securing the Iraqi capital, but bombings by Sunni militants have emerged as a greater danger.
articles.abstract: Shiite militias had been seen as the main worry in securing the Iraqi capital, but bombings by Sunni militants have emerged as a greater danger.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 17 — In January, when President Bush announced his plans to reinforce American troops in Baghdad, Shiite militias were seen as the main worry. Some analysts predicted that bloody clashes with Shiite militants in the Sadr City district in northeastern Baghdad were all but inevitable.

articles.headline: Hot but Virtuous Is an Unlikely Match for an Online Dating Service
articles.snippet: In part because of its provocative ads, True.com has become one of the most popular and controversial sites in the online dating industry.
articles.abstract: In part because of its provocative ads, True.com has become one of the most popular and controversial sites in the online dating industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The women who appear in Web ads for the dating site True.com almost certainly do not need to look online for a date.

articles.headline: In Shriner Spending, a Blurry Line of Giving
articles.snippet: A Times examination paints a picture of lax accounting procedures and oversight of money earmarked for Shriners hospitals.
articles.abstract: A Times examination paints a picture of lax accounting procedures and oversight of money earmarked for Shriners hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABILENE, Tex. — John C. Goline is living proof of the good work done by the Shriners. Struck by polio as a child, he can walk today only because of his six years in and out of the Shriners hospital in Shreveport, La., where, like all patients, he received free treatment.

articles.headline: Partner Adopted by an Heiress Stakes Her Claim
articles.snippet: The former lesbian partner of the granddaughter of the founder of I.B.M. is seeking a share of an inherited fortune.
articles.abstract: The former lesbian partner of the granddaughter of the founder of I.B.M. is seeking a share of an inherited fortune.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH HAVEN, Me., March 13  On an island liberally sprinkled with the affluent and well-connected members of such clans as Bush, du Pont, Rockefeller and Cabot, the Watson family occupies a special place.
articles.byline: By Pam Belluck and Alison Leigh Cowan

articles.headline: Tilting Hollywood’s Balance of Power to Talent Agency Clients
articles.snippet: A fledgling film-financing company may give filmmakers and stars more earning power and ownership of their projects.
articles.abstract: A fledgling film-financing company may give filmmakers and stars more earning power and ownership of their projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, March 18 — Almost six years ago, big thinkers at Hollywood’s Endeavor talent agency, best known as the players behind the industry satire “Entourage” on HBO, drilled into a bothersome question: Why should a star or director work for low pay on a labor of love only to see a film studio or foreign sales company strike it rich if the movie thrives in worldwide theatrical and video markets?

articles.headline: Barclays Bank Makes Inquiry on Takeover of ABN Amro
articles.snippet: A takeover of ABN by Barclays would be the largest crossborder merger ever in the European banking industry.
articles.abstract: A takeover of ABN by Barclays would be the largest crossborder merger ever in the European banking industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, March 19 — Barclays, one of Britain’s largest banks, has made an informal takeover approach for ABN Amro Holding, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure from hedge funds to consider a merger or asset sales to bolster its lagging share price.

articles.headline: All the World’s a Story
articles.snippet: Assignment Zero, a new online journalism experiment, will use the combined reporting efforts of readers to tell the world a story.
articles.abstract: Assignment Zero, a new online journalism experiment, will use the combined reporting efforts of readers to tell the world a story.
articles.lead_paragraph: Journalism has always been a product of networks. A reporter receives an assignment, begins calling “sources” — people he or she knows or can find. More calls follow and, with luck and a deadline looming, the reporter will gain enough mastery of the topic to sit down at a keyboard and tell the world a story.

articles.headline: Viacom’s Full-Court Press for Online Ads
articles.snippet: Video advertising is the fastest-growing advertising category online, and Viacom is investing aggressively.
articles.abstract: Video advertising is the fastest-growing advertising category online, and Viacom is investing aggressively.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justin Timberlake did not attend Nickelodeon’s annual advertising presentation this month, but one of Viacom’s own ad sales executives, Jim Tricarico, took the stage to perform a rendition of the singer’s “SexyBack.”

articles.headline: A New Sorrow for Afghanistan: AIDS Joins List
articles.snippet: In the deeply conservative country, H.I.V. remains underground, shrouded in ignorance and stigma.
articles.abstract: In the deeply conservative country, H.I.V. remains underground, shrouded in ignorance and stigma.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 13 — Sitting and eating quietly on his father’s lap, the 18-month-old was oblivious to the infection in his veins.
